sub_topic: Using integration to find the work done by a force
message_1: A force of 20 N pulls a crate a distance of 10 meters along a straight line on a level floor. If the force is applied at an angle of 30 degrees with the horizontal, find the work done in moving the crate using integration.
message_2:
To find the work done in moving the crate, we need to calculate the horizontal component of the force that is actually moving the crate along the level floor. Since the force is applied at an angle of 30 degrees with the horizontal, we can use the cosine function to find the horizontal component of the force.

F_horizontal = F * cos(θ)
F_horizontal = 20 N * cos(30°)

Converting the angle to radians:
30° * (π/180) = π/6 radians

F_horizontal = 20 N * cos(π/6)
F_horizontal ≈ 20 N * 0.866
F_horizontal ≈ 17.32 N

Now, we need to find the work done (W) in moving the crate. Work done is the product of the horizontal force and the distance moved in the direction of the force.

W = F_horizontal * distance
W = 17.32 N * 10 m
W ≈ 173.2 J (Joules)

Therefore, the work done in moving the crate is approximately 173.2 Joules.
